abstract_summ: In sputum, 17 patients (51.5%) had undetectable viral RNA within 22 days (short persistence), and 16 (48.5%) had persistent viral RNA more than 22 days (long persistence).Overall, 15.3% (676 of 4,428 positive results) of positive results had viral loads greater than 8 log10 copies/mL, with occasional samples exceeding 10 log10 copies/mL. These results support quantitative assessment of SARS-CoV-2 viral load in patient testing and efforts to control viral transmissionBACKGROUND: The current outbreak of COVID‐19 has spread rapidly all over the world.Interpretation: Serum SARS-CoV-2 viral load (RNAaemia) is strongly associated with cytokine storm and can be used to predict the poor prognosis of COVID-19 patients.One patient had persistent viral RNA for 59 days or longer.Background: Laboratory diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection (the cause of COVID-19) uses PCR to detect viral RNA (vRNA) in respiratory samples.
title_summ: Comparison of throat swabs and sputum specimens for viral nucleic acid detection in 52 cases of novel coronavirus (SARS-Cov-2) infected pneumonia (COVID-19)An analysis of SARS-CoV-2 viral load by patient agePersistent SARS-CoV-2 replication in severe COVID-19High frequency of SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia and association with severe diseaseDetectable serum SARS-CoV-2 viral load (RNAaemia) is closely associated with drastically elevated interleukin 6 (IL-6) level in critically ill COVID-19 patientsSARS-CoV-2 RNA detected in blood samples from patients with COVID-19 is not associated with infectious virusLong period dynamics of viral load and antibodies for SARS-CoV-2 infection: an observational cohort studyThe novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pneumonia with negative detection of viral ribonucleic acid from nasopharyngeal swabs: a case reportStudy of SARS-CoV-2 in semen and urine samples of a volunteer with positive naso-pharyngeal swabDetectable serum SARS-CoV-2 viral load (RNAaemia) is closely correlated with drastically elevated interleukin 6 (IL-6) level in critically ill COVID-19 patientsSARS-CoV-2 Viral load Assessment in Respiratory SamplesPositive detection of SARS‐CoV‐2 combined HSV1 and HHV6B virus nucleic acid in tear and conjunctival secretions of a non‐conjunctivitis COVID‐19 patient with obstruction of common lacrimal ductDetection and Isolation of SARS-CoV-2 in Serum, Urine, and Stool Specimens of COVID-19 Patients from the Republic of KoreaAssessment of SARS-CoV-2 in human semen - a cohort studyPredicting infectious SARS-CoV-2 from diagnostic samplesTemporal profiles of viral load in posterior oropharyngeal saliva samples and serum antibody responses during infection by SARS-CoV-2: an observational cohort studyDetection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in fecal specimens of patients with confirmed COVID-19: a meta-analysisSARS‐CoV‐2 can be detected in urine, blood, anal swabs, and oropharyngeal swabs specimensDifferences of SARS-CoV-2 Shedding Duration in Sputum and Nasopharyngeal Swab Specimens among Adult Inpatients with COVID-19Detecting SARS-CoV-2 RNA in conjunctival secretions: is it a valuable diagnostic method of COVID-19?Detection of SARS-CoV-2 in Human Retinal Biopsies of Deceased COVID-19 Patients.Comparison of throat swabs and sputum specimens for viral nucleic acid detection in 52 cases of novel coronavirus (SARS-Cov-2)-infected pneumonia (COVID-19).Evaluation of Conjunctival Swab PCR Results in Patients with SARS-CoV-2 Infection.Viral loads in throat and anal swabs in children infected with SARS-CoV-2.Presence of viral RNA of SARS-CoV-2 in conjunctival swab specimens of COVID-19 patients.
title_abstract_phrases: Overall, 15.3% (676 of 4,428 positive results) of positive results had viral loads greater than 8 log10 copies/mL, with occasional samples exceeding 10 log10 copies/mL. These results support quantitative assessment of SARS-CoV-2 viral load in patient testing and efforts to control viral transmissionPositive detection of SARS‐CoV‐2 combined HSV1 and HHV6B virus nucleic acid in tear and conjunctival secretions of a non‐conjunctivitis COVID‐19 patient with obstruction of common lacrimal ductBACKGROUND: The current outbreak of COVID‐19 has spread rapidly all over the world.Conclusion: This study demonstrated a high proportion of SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia, and an association between RNAemia and clinical severity suggesting the potential utility of plasma viral testing as a prognostic indicator for COVID-19.Detectable serum SARS-CoV-2 viral load (RNAaemia) is closely associated with drastically elevated interleukin 6 (IL-6) level in critically ill COVID-19 patientsBackground: Although the SARS-CoV-2 viral load detection of respiratory specimen has been widely used for novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) diagnosis, it is undeniable that serum SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid (RNAaemia) could be detected in a fraction of the COVID-19 patients.In sputum, 17 patients (51.5%) had undetectable viral RNA within 22 days (short persistence), and 16 (48.5%) had persistent viral RNA more than 22 days (long persistence).Detecting SARS-CoV-2 RNA in conjunctival secretions: is it a valuable diagnostic method of COVID-19?PURPOSE To evaluate the presence of viral RNA of SARS-CoV-2 in conjunctival swab specimen of COVID-19 patients with and without conjunctivitis to establish the diagnostic value of reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) in each case and to describe its clinical characteristics.Interpretation: Serum SARS-CoV-2 viral load (RNAaemia) is strongly associated with cytokine storm and can be used to predict the poor prognosis of COVID-19 patients.
